Was I betroth’d, ere I ſee Hermia,
But like a ſickeneſſe did I loath this food,
But as in health, come to my naturall taſte,
Now doe I wiſh it, loue it, long for it,
And will for euermore be true to it.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: Faire Louers, you are fortunately met;
Of this diſcourſe we ſhall heare more anon.
Egeus, I will ouer-beare your will;
For in the Temple, by and by with vs,
Theſe couples ſhall eternally be knit.
And for the morning now is ſomething worne,
Our purpos’d hunting ſhall be ſet aside.
Away, with vs to Athens; three and three,
Wee'll hold a feaſt in great ſolemnitie.
Come Hippolita.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Theſe things ſeeme ſmall & vndiſtinguiſhable,
Like farre off mountaines turned into Clouds.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: Me-thinks I ſee theſe things with parted eye,
When euery thing ſeemes double.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: So me-thinkes:
And I haue found Demetrius, like a iewell,
Mine owne, and not mine owne.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: It ſeemes to mee,
That yet we ſleepe, we dreame. Do not you thinke,
The Duke was heere, and bid vs follow him?

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: Yea, and my Father.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: And Hippolita.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: And he bid vs follow to the Temple.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Why then we are awake; lets follow him, and
by the way let vs recount our dreames.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: When my cue comes, call me, and I will anſwer.
My next is, moſt faire Piramus. Hey ho. Peter Quince?
Flute the bellowes-mender? Snout the tinker? Starue-
ling? Gods my life! Stolne hence, and left me aſleepe: I
haue had a moſt rare viſion. I had a dreame, paſt the wit
of man, to ſay, what dreame it was. Man is but an Aſſe,
if he goe about to expound this dreame. Me-thought I
was, there is no man can tell what. Me-thought I was,
and me-thought I had. But man is but a patch’d foole,
if he will offer to ſay, what me-thought I had. The eye of
man hath not heard, the eare of man hath not ſeen, mans
hand is not able to taſte, his tongue to conceiue, nor his
heart to report, what my dreame was. I will get Peter
Quince to write a ballet of this dreame, it ſhall be called
Bottomes Dreame, becauſe it hath no bottome; and I will
ſing it in the latter end of a play, before the Duke. Per—
aduenture, to make it the more gracious, I ſhall ſing it
at her death.

scene.stagedir: Enter Quince, Flute, Thisbie, Snout, and Starueling.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: Haue you ſent to Bottomes house? Is he come
home yet?

speech.speaker: Staru.
speech.line: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt hee is
tranſported.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: If he come not, then the play is mar’d. It goes
not forward, doth it?

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: It is not poſſible: you haue not a man in all
Athens, able to discharge Piramus but he.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: No, hee hath ſimply the beſt wit of any handy—
craft man in Athens.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: Yea, and the beſt perſon too, and hee is a very
Paramour, for a ſweet voyce.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: You muſt ſay, Paragon. A Paramour is (God
bleſſe vs) a thing of nought.

speech.speaker: Snug.
speech.line: Maſters, the Duke is comming from the Tem—
ple, and there is two or three Lords & Ladies more mar—
ried. If our ſport had gone forward, we had all bin made
men.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: O ſweet bully Bottome: thus hath he loſt ſixe—
pence a day, during his life; he could not haue ſcaped ſix—
pence a day. And the Duke had not giuen him ſixpence
a day for playing Piramus, Ile be hang’d. He would haue
deſerued it. Sixpence a day in Piramus, or nothing.

speech.speaker: Bot.
speech.line: Where are theſe Lads? Where are theſe hearts?

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: Bottome, ô moſt couragious day! O moſt hap—
pie houre!

speech.speaker: Bot.
speech.line: Maſters, I am to diſcourſe wonders; but ask me
not what. For if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I
will tell you euery thing as it fell out.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Let vs heare, ſweet Bottome.

speech.speaker: Bot.
speech.line: Not a word of me: all that I will tell you, is, that
the Duke hath dined. Get your apparell together, good
ſtrings to your beards, new ribbands to your pumps,
meete preſently at the Palace, euery man looke ore his
part: for the ſhort and the long is, our play is preferred:
In any caſe let Thiſby haue cleane linnen: and let not him
that playes the Lion, paire his nailes, for they ſhall hang
out for the Lions clawes. And moſt deare Aƈtors, eate
no Onions, nor Garlicke; for wee are to vtter ſweete
breath, and I doe not doubt but to heare them ſay, it is a
ſweet Comedy. No more words: away, go away.

scene.stagedir: Enter Theſeus, Hippolita, Egeus and his Lords.

speech.speaker: Hip.
speech.line: ‘Tis ſtrange my Theſeus, ý theſe louers ſpeake of.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: More ſtrange then true. I neuer may beleeue
Theſe anticke fables, nor theſe Fairy toyes,
Louers and mad men haue ſuch ſeething braines,
Such ſhaping phantaſies, that apprehend more
Then coole reaſon euer comprehends.
The Lunaticke, the Louer, and the Poet,
Are of imagination all compaƈt.
One ſees more diuels then vaſte hell can hold;
That is the mad man. The Louer, all as franticke,
Sees Helens beauty in a brow of Egipt.
The Poets eye in a fine frenzy rolling, doth glance
From heauen to earth, from earth to heauen.
And as imagination bodies forth the forms of things
Vnknowne; the Poets pen turnes them to ſhapes,
And giues to aire nothing, a locall habitation,
And a name. Such tricks hath ſtrong imagination,
That if it would but apprehend ſome ioy,
It comprehends ſome bringer of that ioy.
Or in the night, imagining ſome feare,
Howe eaſie is a buſh ſuppos’d a Beare?

speech.speaker: Hip.
speech.line: But all the ſtorie of the night told ouer,
And all their minds transfigur’d ſo together,
More witneſſeth than fancies images,
And growes to ſomething of great conſtancie;
But howsſoeuer, ſtrange, and admirable.

scene.stagedir: Enter louers, Lyſander, Demetrius, Hermia, and Helena.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: Heere come the louers, full of ioy and mirth:
Ioy, gentle friends, ioy and freſh dayes
Of loue accompany your hearts.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: More then to vs, waite in your royall walkes,
your boord, your bed.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: Come now, what maskes, what dances ſhall
we haue,
To weare away this long age of three houres,
Between our after ſupper, and bed-time?
Where is our vsuall manager of mirth?
What Reuels are in hand? Is there no play,
To eaſe the anguiſh of a torturing houre?
Call Egeus.

speech.speaker: Ege.
speech.line: Heere mighty Theſeus.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: Say, what abridgement haue you for this eue—
ning?
What maske? What muſicke? How ſhall we beguile
The lazie time, if not with ſome delight?

speech.speaker: Ege.
speech.line: There is a breefe how many ſports are rife:
Make choiſe of which your Highneſſe will ſee firſt.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: The battell with the Centaurs to be ſung
By an Athenian Eunuch, to the Harpe.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: Wee’l none of that. That haue I told my Loue
In glory of my kinſman Hercules.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: The riot of the tipſie Bachanals,
Tearing the Thracian ſinger, in their rage?

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: That is an old deuice, and it was plaid
When I from Thebes came laſt a Conqueror.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: The thrice three Muſes, mourning for the death
of learning, late deceaſt in beggerie.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: That is ſome Satire keene and criticall,
Not ſorting with a nuptiall ceremonie.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: A tedious breefe Scene of yong Piramus,
And his loue Thisby; very tragicall mirth.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: Merry and tragicall? Tedious, and briefe? That
is, hot ice, and wondrous ſtrange ſnow. How ſhall wee
finde the concord of this diſcord?

speech.speaker: Ege.
speech.line: A play there is, my Lord, ſome ten words long,
Which is as breefe, as I haue knowne a play;
But by ten words, my Lord, it is too long;
Which makes it tedious. For in all the play,
There is not one word apt, one Player fitted.
And tragicall my noble Lord it is: for Piramus
Therein doth kill himſelfe. Which when I ſaw
Rehearſt, I muſt confeſſe, made mine eyes water:
But more merrie teares, the paſſion of loud laughter
Neuer ſhed.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: What are they that do play it?

speech.speaker: Ege.
speech.line: Hard handed men, that worke in Athens heere,
Which neuer labour’d in their mindes till now;
And now haue toyled their vnbreathed memories
With this ſame play, against your nuptiall.

speech.speaker: The.
speech.line: And we will heare it.

speech.speaker: Phi.
speech.line: No my noble Lord, it is not for you. I haue heard
It ouer, and it is nothing, nothing in the world;
Vnleſſe you can finde ſport in their intents,
Extreamely ſtretcht, and cond with cruell paine,
To doe you ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: I will heare that play. For neuer any thing
Can be amiſſe, when ſimpleneſſe and duty tender it.
Goe bring them in, and take your places, Ladies.

speech.speaker: Hip.
speech.line: I loue not to ſee wretchedneſſe orecharged;
And duty in his ſeruice periſhing.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: Why gentle ſweet, you ſhall ſee no ſuch thing.

speech.speaker: Hip.
speech.line: He ſaies, they can doe nothing in this kinde.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: The kinder we, to giue them thanks for nothing
Our ſport ſhall be, to take what they miſtake;
And what poore duty cannot doe, noble respeƈt
Takes it in might, not merit.
Where I haue come, great Clearkes haue purpoſed
To greete me with premeditated welcomes;
Where I haue ſeene them ſhiuer and looke pale,
Make periods in the midſt of ſentences,
Throttle their praƈtiz’d accent in their feares,
And in concluſion, dumbly haue broke off,
Not paying me a welcome. Truſt me ſweete,
Out of this ſilence yet, I pickt a welcome:
And in the modeſty of fearefull duty,
I read as much, as from the ratling tongue
Of ſaucy and audacious eloquence.
Loue therefore, and tongue-tide ſimplicity,
In leaſt, ſpeake moſt, to my capacity.

speech.speaker: Egeus.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Grace, the Prologue is addreſt.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Let him approach.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: If we offend, it is with our good will.
That you ſhould thinke, we come not to offend,
But with good will. To ſhew our ſimple ſkill,
That is the true beginning of our end.
Conſider then, we come but in deſpight.
We do not come, as minding to content you,
Our true intent is. All for your delight,
We are not heere. That you ſhould here repent you,
The Aƈtors are at hand; and by their ſhow,
You ſhall know all, that you are like to know.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: This fellow doth not ſtand vpon points.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: He hath rid his Prologue, like a rough Colt: he
knowes not the ſtop. A good morall my Lord. It is not
enough to ſpeake, but to ſpeake true.

speech.speaker: Hip.
speech.line: Indeed hee hath plaid on his Prologue, like a
childe on a Recorder, a ſound, but not in gouernment.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: His ſpeech was like a tangled chaine: nothing
impaired, but all diſordered. Who is next?

scene.stagedir: Tawyer with a Trumpet before them.
Enter Pyramus and Thisby, Wall, Moone-ſhine, and Lyon.

speech.speaker: Prol.
speech.line: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this ſhow,
But wonder on, till truth make all things plaine.
This man is Piramus, if you would know;
This beauteous Lady, Thisby is certaine.
This man, with lyme and rough-caſt, doth preſent
Wall, that vile wall, which did theſe louers ſunder:
And through walls chink (poor ſoules) they are content
To whiſper. At the which, let no man wonder.
This man, with Lanthorne, dog, and buſh of thorne,
Preſenteth moone-ſhine. For if you will know,
By moone-ſhine did theſe Louers thinke no ſcorne
To meet at Ninus toombe, there, there to wooe;:
This grizly beaſt (which Lyon hight by name)
The truſty Thisby, comming firſt by night,
Did ſcarre away, or rather did affright:
And as ſhe fled, her mantle ſhe did fall;
Which Lyon vile with bloody mouth did ſtaine.
Anon comes Piramus, ſweet youth and tall,
And findes his Thisbies Mantle ſlaine;
Whereat, with blade, with bloody blamefull blade,
He brauely broacht his boiling bloudy breaſt,
And Thisby, tarrying in Mulberry ſhade,
His dagger drew, and died. For all the reſt,
Let Lyon, Moone-ſhine, Wall, and Louers twaine,
At large diſcourse, while here they doe remaine.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: I wonder if the Lion be to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: No wonder, my Lord: one Lion may, when
many Aſſes doe.

speech.speaker: Wall.
speech.line: In this ſame Interlude, it doth befall,
That I, one Snowt (by name) preſent a wall:
And ſuch a wall, as I vvould haue you thinke,
That had in it a crannied hole or chinke:
Through which the Louers, Piramus and Thisbie
Did whiſper often, very ſecretly.
This loame, this rough-caſt, and this ſtone doth ſhew,
That I am that ſame Wall; the truth is ſo.
And this the cranny is, right and ſiniſter,
Through which the fearfull Louers are to whiſper.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: Would you deſire Lime and Haire to ſpeake
better?

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: It is the vvittieſt partition, that euer I heard
diſcourſe, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: Pyramus drawes neere the Wall, ſilence.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: O grim lookt night, ô night with hue ſo blacke,
O night, which euer art, when day is not:
O night, ô night, alacke, alacke, alacke,
I feare my Thisbies promiſe is forgot.
And thou ô vvall, thou ſweet and louely vvall,
That ſtands between her fathers ground and mine,
Thou vvall, ô vvall, ô ſweet and louely vvall,
Shew me thy chinke, to blinke through vvith mine eine.
Thankes courteous vvall. Ioue ſhield thee vvell for this.
But vvhat ſee I? No Thisbie doe I ſee.
O vvicked vvall, through vvhom I ſee no bliſſe,
Curſt be thy ſtones for thus deceiuing mee.

speech.speaker: Theſ.
speech.line: The vvall me-thinkes being ſenſible, ſhould
curse againe.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: No in truth ſir, he ſhould not. Deceiuing me,
Is Thisbies cue; ſhe is to enter, and I am to ſpy
Her through the vvall. You ſhall ſee it will fall.
Pat as I told you; yonder ſhe comes.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: O vvall, full often haſt thou heard my mones,
For parting my faire Piramus, and me
My cherry lips haue often kiſt thy ſtones;
Thy ſtones with Lime and Haire knit vp in thee.

speech.speaker: Pyra.
speech.line: I ſee a voyce; now vvill I to the chinke,
To ſpy and I can heare my Thisbies face. Thisbie?

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: My Loue thou art, my Loue I thinke.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: Thinke vvhat thou vvilt, I am thy Louers grace,
And like Limander am I truſty ſtill.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: And like Helen till the Fates me kill.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: Not Shafalus to Procrus, was ſo true.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: O kiſſe me through the hole of this vile wall.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: I kiſſe the wals hole, not your lips at all.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: Wilt thou at Ninnies tombe meete me ſtraight
way?

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: Tide life, tide death, I come without delay.

speech.speaker: Wall.
speech.line: Thus haue I Wall, my part diſcharged ſo;
And being done, thus Wall away doth go.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Now is the morall downe between the two
Neighbours.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: No remedie my Lord, when Wals are ſo wil—
full, to heare without vvarning.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: This is the ſilliest ſtuffe that ere I heard.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: The beſt in this kind are but ſhadowes, and the
worſt are no worſe, if imagination amend them.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: It muſt be your imagination then, & not theirs.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: If wee imagine no worſe of them then they of
themſelues, they may paſſe for excellent men. Here com
two noble beaſts, in a man and a Lion.

speech.speaker: Lyon.
speech.line: You Ladies, you (whoſe gentle harts do feare
The ſmalleſt monſtrous mouſe that creepes on floore)
May now perchance, both quake and tremble heere,
When Lion rough in wildeſt rage doth roare.
Then know that I, one Snug the Ioyner am
A Lion fell, nor elſe no Lions dam:
For if I ſhould as Lion come in ſtrife
Into this place, ‘twere pittie of my life.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: A verie gentle beaſt, and of good conſcience.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: The verie beſt at a beaſt, my Lord, ý ere I ſaw.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: This Lion is a verie Fox for his valor.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: True, and a Gooſe for his diſcretion.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Not ſo my Lord: for his valor cannot carrie
his diſcretion, and the fox carries the Gooſe.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: His diſcretion I am ſure cannot carrie his valor:
for the Gooſe carries not the Fox. It is well; leaue it to
his diſcretion, and let vs hearken to the Moone.

speech.speaker: Moone.
speech.line: This Lanthorne doth the horned Moone pre—
ſent.

speech.speaker: De.
speech.line: He ſhould haue worne the hornes on his head.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Hee is no creſcent, and his hornes are inuiſible,
within the circumference.

speech.speaker: Moon.
speech.line: This lanthorne doth the horned Moone pre—
sent: My ſelfe, the man i’th Moone doth ſeeme to be.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: This is the greateſt error of all the reſt; the man
ſhould be put into the Lanthorne. How is it els the man
i’th Moone?

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: He dares not come there for the candle.
For you ſee, it is already in ſnuffe.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: I am vvearie of this Moone; vvould he would
change.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: It appeares by his ſmal light of diſcretion, that
he is in the wane: but yet in courteſie, in all reaſon, vve
muſt ſtay the time.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: Proceed Moone.

speech.speaker: Moon.
speech.line: All that I haue to ſay, is to tell you, that the
Lanthorne is the Moone; I, the man in the Moone; this
thorne buſh; my thorne buſh; and this dog, my dog.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Why all theſe ſhould be in the Lanthorne: for
they are in the Moone. But ſilence, heere comes Thisby.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: This is old Ninnies tombe: where is my loue?

speech.speaker: Lyon.
speech.line: Oh.

scene.stagedir: The Lion roares, Thisby runs off.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Well roar’d Lion.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Well run Thisby.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Well ſhone Moone.
Truly the Moone ſhines with a good grace.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Wel mouz’d Lion.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: And then came Piramus.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: And ſo the Lion vaniſht.

speech.speaker: Pyr.
speech.line: Sweet Moone, I thank thee for thy ſunny beames,
I thanke thee Moone, for ſhining now ſo bright:
For by thy gracious, golden, glittering beames,
I truſt to taſte of trueſt Thisbies ſight.
But ſtay: O ſpight! but marke, poore Knight,
What dreadful dole is heere?
Eyes do you ſee! How can it be!
O dainty Ducke: O Deere!
Thy mantle good; what ſtaind with blood!
Approch you Furies fell:
O Fates! come, come: Cut thred and thrum,
Quaile, cruſh, conclude, and quell.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: This paſſion, and the death of a deare friend,
Would go neere to make a man looke ſad.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Beſhrew my heart, but I pittie the man.

speech.speaker: Pir.
speech.line: O wherefore Nature, did’ſt thou Lions frame?
Since Lion vilde hath heere deflour’d my deere:
Which is: no, no, which was the faireſt Dame
That liu’d, that lou’d, that like’d, that look’d with cheere.
Come teares, confound: Out ſword, and wound
The pap of Piramus:
I, that left pap, where heart doth hop;
Thus dye I, thus, thus, thus.
Now am I dead, now am I fled, my ſoule is in the ſky,
Tongue loſe thy light, Moone take thy flight,
Now dye, dye, dye, dye, dye.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: No Die, but an ace for him; for he is but one.

speech.speaker: Liſ.
speech.line: Leſſe then an ace man. For he is dead, he is no—
thing.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: With the helpe of a Surgeon, he might yet reco—
uer, and proue an Aſſe.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: How chance Moone-ſhine is gone before?
Thisby comes backe, and findes her Louer.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: She wil finde him by ſtarre-light.
Heere ſhe comes, and her paſſion ends the play.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Me thinkes ſhee ſhould not vſe a long one for
ſuch a Piramus: I hope ſhe will be breefe.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: A Moth wil turne the ballance, which Piramus
which Thisby is the better.

speech.speaker: Lyſ.
speech.line: She hath ſpyed him already, with thoſe ſweete eyes.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: And thus ſhe meanes, videlicit.

speech.speaker: Thiſ.
speech.line: Aſleepe my Loue? What, dead my Doue?
O Piramus ariſe:
Speake, ſpeake. Quite dumbe? Dead, dead? A tombe
Muſt couer thy ſweet eyes.
Theſe Lilly Lips, this cherry noſe,
Theſe yellow Cowſlip cheekes
Are gone, are gone: Louers make mone:
His eyes were greene as Leekes.
O ſiſters three, come, come to mee,
With hands as pale as Milke,
Lay them in gore, ſince you haue ſhore
with ſheeres, his thred of ſilke.
Tongue not a word: Come truſty ſword:
Come blade, my breſt imbrue:
And farwell friends, thus Thisbie ends;
Adieu, adieu, adieu.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Moone-ſhine & Lion are left to burie the dead.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: I, and Wall too.

speech.speaker: Bot.
speech.line: No, I aſſure you, the wall is downe, that parted
their Fathers. Will it pleaſe you to ſee the Epilogue, or
to heare a Bergomask dance, betweene two of our com—
pany?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: No Epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs
no excuſe. Neuer excuſe; for when the plaiers are all
dead, there need none to be blamed. Marry, if hee that
writ it had plaid Piramus, and hung himſelfe in Thisbies
garter, it would haue beene a fine Tragedy: and ſo it is
truely, and very notably diſcharg’d. but come, your
Burgomaske; let your Epilogue alone.
The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelue.
Louers to bed, ‘tis almoſt Fairy time.
I feare we ſhall out-ſleepe the comming morne,
As much as we this night haue ouer-watcht.
This palpable groſſe play hath well beguil’d
The heauy gate of night. Sweet friends to bed.
A fortnight hold we this ſolemnity.
In nightly Reuels; and new iollitie.

speech.speaker: Puck.
speech.line: Now the hungry Lyons rores,
And the Wolfe beholds the Moone:
Whileſt the heauy ploughman ſnores,
All with weary taske fore-done.
Now the waſted brands doe glow,
Whil’ſt the ſcritch-owle, ſcritching loud,
Puts the wretch that lies in woe,
In remembrance of a ſhrowd.
Now it is the time of night,
That the graues, all gaping wide,
Euery one lets forth his ſpright,
In the Church-way paths to glide,
And we Fairies, that do runne,
By the triple Hecates teame,
From the preſence of the Sunne,
Following darkeneſſe like a dreame,
Now are frollicke; not a Mouſe
Shall diſturbe this hallowed houſe.
I am ſent with broome before,
To ſweep the duſt behinde the doore.

scene.stagedir: Enter King and Queene of Fairies, with their traine.

speech.speaker: Ob.
speech.line: Through the houſe giue glimmering light,
By the dead and drowſie fier,
Euerie Elfe and Fairie ſpright,
Hop as light as bird from brier,
And this Ditty after me, ſing and dance it trippinglie.

speech.speaker: Tita.
speech.line: Firſt rehearſe this ſong by roate,
To each word a warbling note.
Hand in hand, with Fairie grace,
Will we ſing and bleſſe this place.

song.line: Now vntill the breake of day,
Through this houſe each Fairy ſtray.
To the beſt Bride-bed will we,
Which by vs ſhall bleſſed be:
And the iſſue there create,
Euer ſhall be fortunate:
So ſhall all the couples three,
Euer true in louing be:
And the blots of Natures hand,
Shall not in their iſſue ſtand.
Neuer mole, harelip, nor ſcarre,
Nor marke prodigious, ſuch as are
Deſpiſed in Natiuitie,
Shall vpon their children be.
With this field dew conſecrate,
Euery Fairy take his gate,
And each ſeuerall chamber bleſſe,
Through this Pallace with ſweet peace,
Euer ſhall in ſafety reſt.
And the owner of it bleſt.
Trip away, make no ſtay;
Meet me all by breake of day.

speech.speaker: Robin.
speech.line: If we ſhadowes haue offended,
Thinke but this (and all is mended)
That you haue but ſlumbred heere,
While theſe viſions did appeare.
And this weake and idle theame,
No more yeelding but a dreame,
Gentles, doe not reprehend.
If you pardon, we will mend.
And as I am an honeſt Pucke,
If we haue vnearned lucke,
Now to ſcape the Serpents tongue,
We will make amends ere long:
Elſe the Pucke a lyar call.
So good night vnto you all.
Giue me your hands, if we be friends,
And Robin ſhall reſtore amends.
